Theological Fatalism: Pike’s argument and God’s omniscience
5. Theological Fatalism: Pike’s argument and God’s omniscience

A problem which has been much discussed by philosophers, at least
since the time of Augustine (354–430), is whether divine
omniscience is compatible with free will, and in particular with our
having the power to do other than we do.

One way of arguing for this incompatibility is due to Pike (Pike
1965).


Let us suppose that being omniscient involves being infallible, and
believing that p if and only if it is true that
p.

Let us also suppose that God existed in 1900, and that omniscience is
part of his essence.

Now, suppose that Jones mowed his lawn on 1/1/2000.

Then God believed in 1900 that Jones would mow his lawn on
1/1/2000.

Did Jones have the power to refrain from mowing his lawn?

No. Because that would mean either (1) that he had the power to do
something which would have brought it about that God had a false
belief in 1900, or (2) that he had the power to do something which
would have brought it about that God did not believe in 1900 that
Jones would mow his lawn on 1/1/2000, or (3) that he had the power to
do something which would have brought it about that God did not exist
in 1900. And each of these alternatives is impossible.


Are there any objections to this argument?

Naturally it would be possible to object to some of the suppositions
about the existence and nature of God. I will return to them.

First we should notice that the argument depends on a certain
principle about power which is very similar to the plausible amended
version of Taylor’s presupposition 5:

If it is in S’s power to do something which would bring
it about that p, and p entails q, and
q is false, then it is in S’s power to do
something which would bring it about that q .


This seems plausible. One might, though, prefer to avoid all mention
of bringing about, and to rephrase the argument in terms of
counterfactuals. So, one would say instead, “…that would
mean either (1) that he had the power so to act that God would have
had a false belief in 1900, or …” (Fischer 1989,
8–11) However, the argument seems at least as plausible when
rephrased in this way.

Since, given Pike’s assumptions about the existence and nature of
God, it would have been impossible for Jones to act in such a way
that God would have had a false belief or would not have existed, we
can confine our attention to the question of whether he had the power
so to act that God would not have believed in 1900 that he would mow
the lawn on 1/1/2000.

Plantinga (1974a, Part 1, b) claims that the argument
fails to show that Jones did not have the power to refrain from
mowing since there is a possible world in which he refrained from
mowing, and so a possible world in which he acted in such a way
that God would not have believed that he would mow. Pike
replies (Pike 1977) that the fact that there is such a
possible world is not enough to show that Jones had the power to
refrain; he cites the fact that there is a possible world in which he
jumps ten feet, but says that that does not mean that he has the power
to jump ten feet.

It seems that, if Plantinga were right, there would be a ready answer
to the claim that powerlessness to do anything other than what we
actually do follows from causal determnism; in particular to the
claim that, if Jones’s mowing were causally determined by
circumstances, natural or supernatural, prior to his birth, he would
not have the power to refrain. The answer would be that there was a
possible world in which the circumstances before his birth were such
as not to prevent Jones from mowing.

However, it is beyond the scope of this entry to discuss the question
of whether the power to do anything other than what we actually do is
compatible with causal determinism. Let us, therefore, consider
whether there is any other reason for thinking that Jones might
have had the power to act in such a way that God would not have
believed that he would mow the lawn on 1/1/2000.
